comments.body: Do these other libraries need to be in `run` also?

They are not strict dependencies, that is, sdl2_mixer will work without them, but is not able to decode the audioformats if the libraries are not present. I think it is better to leave it up to the user to include the libraries they think to need.
Moreover, I compiled sdl2_mixer against the static audio libraries, and as far as my limited C compilation knowledge goes, this means that you don't need the {dlls|dylibs|so} of these libraries, but that they are (partly) included in the sdl2_mixer module itself. Correct me if I'm wrong.
Hmm...why not link to them dynamically? It seems this is the benefit of having a package manager.
Should add that on Unix it is probably linking these dynamically.
Yeah, I tend to agree that dynamic linking is better in the package management space. Maybe there is a test that actually loads the library so that we know it is working?

Yes, I agree that it is better to link dynamically, and yes, on linux it always does so. However, since the build/configure script looks for these libraries, I thought it was smarter to include them at build time, even though I don't know if it has any benefits/consequences for the resulting build.

On Windows on the other hand, it can be more difficult because sdl2_mixer doesn't always look for the libraries at the correct places. I was advised to compile sdl2_mixer against the static libraries, as I do here. And, as far as I know, sdl2_mixer first tries to look for and use the dynamic libraries and uses these statically linked libraries as a fallback if it can't find them.

EDIT: mean fallback instead of callback of course.

Sure, I am not going to be a stickler if you have something working.  

The impact that the difference has that we are concerned about here is the file / package size.
I was also worried about this, but the resulting package is around 200kb when I last checked, but I can't really verify as I'm not on a Windows machine at the moment.
